TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The incidence of disability retirement for permanent Public Service staff who come under the ambit of the Australian Public Service Board is averaged over the years 1970 to 1982 inclusive. From the tables it can be seen that there has been an average of one disability retirement each year for every 120 public servants. The incidence has varied over the years, as will be noted later. Combining all age groups, it was one in 200 in 1970, rising to one in 67 in 1977 and 1978, declining to one in 83 in 1979, and declining again to one in 170 in 1982. Whilst it is difficult to get reasonably comparable figures from the private sector, some are available and they appear in the tables. Comparisons reveal that the numbers of retirements occasioned by some disability were one in 4,000 in the private sector for people aged under 50, whereas the figure was one in 560 in the Commonwealth Public Service. There were one in 350 such retirements for people aged 50 to 54 in the private sector as against one in 57 amongst public servants; one in 470 for those aged 50 to 59 in the private sector compared with one in 24 in the public sector; and one in 80 for people 60 years of age and over in the private sector as against one in 10 in the public sector. For all age groups combined, the figure for the private sector is one in 900, as opposed to one in 120 in the Commonwealth Public Service. In every case but one, the actual Commonwealth Public Service disability experience is about seven times the rate in the private sector. The one exception in the age group 60 years and over, where the figure is even greater at a factor of nine.

SPEECH.PARA: It is necessary to note here that early retirement and disability retirement in the private sector tend to have the same result in terms of income from superannuation benefits. From that, there is a very important and expensive lesson to be learned. That is, it is impossible to escape the conclusion that the incidence of disability is dependent on the generosity of disability benefits. The better disability benefits are compared with benefits on resignation or retirement on reaching a specified age, the higher will be the rate of disability. There are two criteria which led to this inescapable conclusion. First, disability retirement in the Public Service confers on the beneficiary an entitlement to 70 per cent of his or her final salary, fully indexed for life. By comparison, private sector schemes generally offer a lump sum entitlement on the establishment of a bona fide disability, which typically would be equivalent to somewhere between two and five times the final salary of the beneficiary. Few private sector schemes offer continuing payments, and there are none that are fully indexed as a matter of right. Benefits in the public sector are much more generous.

The second criterion is the influence of disability benefits on the incidence of disability retirement and how they correlate to changes in disability rates for Public Service Board permanent staff during the 1970s. In 1976 the Commonwealth superannuation scheme was redesigned. One of the changes was that disability benefits were much improved. In 1975 the rate of disability retirement for people aged 50 to 54 was one in 75; in 1977 it was one in 32, and in 1978 it was one in 39. Similar, though not identical, movements in the incidence of disability retirements may be seen for other age groups in the years 1977 and 1978. Altogether, the disability retirement figure for the Public Service was one in 160 in 1975 and blew out to one in 67 in 1977 and 1978. It should be stressed that these figures do not indicate the proportion of disability to all retirements, they indicate the proportion of disability retirements to all permanent public servants.

If we ignore comparisons between disability retirements and age retirements, the figures are even more stark. In 1978 almost 1,600 permanent public servants retired on grounds of disability, whereas only 682 retired because of age-that is, a ratio of 70:30. Furthermore, another 270 public servants aged under 50 were retired on grounds of disability, making 1,862 in all-almost three-quarters of all retirements. It is interesting to note that in 1940, 16 per cent of all disability retirements were due to nervous and mental conditions; and by the year 1974-75, 50 per cent of all disability retirements in people under 50 were attributed to neuroses, psychoses symptoms and ill-defined conditions. For the age group 50 to 54 the figure was 41 percent; for 54- to 59-year olds it was 36 per cent; and for all age groups 37 per cent. On the other hand, although the percentage of mental disorders and dubious complaints decreased slightly, the actual numbers involved increased threefold to almost 1,400 public servants, in line with the vast increase in disability retirements, for all reasons after the changes made in 1976.

The dramatic increase in the mid-1970s can be rationally explained only by relating it to changes in the superannuation scheme, which encouraged people to try for disability retirement and its financial advantages instead of simply resigning or hanging on until retiring age was reached. A study should be undertaken to determine how many of those who have retired on disability pensions over the last 14 years have since taken up full time or part time employment, which has no effect on their entitlement to receive their generous indexed pension for life. If the figures do not call into question the quality of medical assessments, it is possible that the subsequent acts and behaviour of disability retirees may. There is absolutely no sign that the role the Department of Health plays in determining the bona fides of those claiming retirement benefits by reason of disability has improved over recent years. On the contrary, the Department's recent decision on the pay of part time relieving Commonwealth medical officers suggests that it does not consider the medical assessment of candidates for disability retirement to be a very responsible job.

There are other fundamental problems arising out of regulations covering public sector superannuation. In particular, the divorcement of each of employment, assessment and Public Service superannuation is illogical. In the private sector , where disability benefits from a superannuation fund have to be financed from company profits or, more often, by premiums paid to a life office, there is an incentive to ensure that people are not taken on unless they are likely to stand up to the stress of the job. Where there is a medical examination, the doctor is conscious of the interests of the employer or the insurer who is paying the fee. In the public sector, it is no skin off the Public Service Board's nose if the superannuation fund has to pay out a few hundred or even a few thousand extra disability pensions. Consequently, there is no incentive for Commonwealth medical officer to go out of his way to identify malingerers or those who would seek to abuse the system. Furthermore, pension payments do not come out of any one department's budget allocation and therefore there is little, if any, concern within the departmental structure if the superannuation fund has to shell out a few tens of thousands or even hundreds of thousands of dollars of taxpayers' money.

What we have recently learnt about the inadequate administration and funding of public sector superannuation schemes in the Commonwealth and the two most populous States lends a good deal of weight to the theory that the trouble is due to the separation of the functions of employment assessment an actual superannuation schemes. These circumstances demand a thorough examination and they demand remedial action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the opportunity today to raise in the House the problems being faced by residents in two areas in my electorate. A reliable telephone system is for most of us an essential part of our business and social lives, so much so that it is usually taken for granted. For the people in Byford making phone calls can be an expensive, frustrating and time- consuming procedure. While the system is more reliable in the Rockingham area, there are still enormous problems presented by the fact that Rockingham is excluded from the Perth telephone district. Rockingham is about 43 kilometres south of Perth by road. It has a residential population of over 26,000 people, which rises to more than 35,000 in the summer. It is a designated growth area which was hit extremely hard during the economic recession. It is part of the Perth metropolitan area and includes the HMAS Stirling naval base within its boundaries. The Shire of Serpentine-Jarrahdale consists of the towns of Byford, Mundijong, Serpentine and Jarrahdale. The whole shire down to Keysbrook is part of the Perth metropolitan area and Mundijong, where the shire headquarters are based, is 48 kilometres from the centre of Perth. However, except for a small part in the north of the shire which is connected to the Forrestdale exchange, the whole area comes under the STD system for calls to the metropolitan area.

SPEECH.PARA: It became very clear to me over recent years that the telephone service provided in the areas I have just mentioned was presenting major problems to the local communities. Earlier this year I invited the Standing Committee on Expenditure Sub-Committee on Telecom Zonal Charging Policies to come to Western Australia so that the various interest groups from Byford, Serpentine, Jarrahdale and Rockingham could present their case on a formal basis. The fundamental problem, at least as far as Western Australia is concerned, is that the boundaries of the zones covering the capital cities have remained substantially unchanged since the 1960s. Telecom, not surprisingly, has received a large number of requests for changes over the years and has responded so far with two new schemes-Community Access 80 and Countrywide Calling. While these significantly improve the situation, there has been concern expressed for some time that a more adequate response is needed.

The Committee's report, which is due to be released very shortly, will address itself to the question of how Telecom's charging policies can be made more equitable and responsive to the needs of the community. The Sub-Committee held a hearing in Perth on 12 June 1984. A considerable amount of time was spent discussing the situation in Byford and Serpentine-Jarrahdale and Rockingham, and tribute must be paid to the men and women who proposed and presented the submissions. One of the main anomalies which emerged from the hearing was that, while Telecom's charging policies are based on radial distances, the development of Perth has taken place in corridors. Mr Bill Mann, the Serpentine-Jarrahdale Shire Clerk, made the point that Perth developed in fingers rather than rings, making the problems in Western Australia quite unique. Councillor Ray Baker, who is the Chairman of the Serpentine-Jarrahdale Committee of the Armadale and Districts Chamber of Commerce, spoke of the inadequacy of the Access 80 scheme and described the quite serious technical problems associated with the local exchanges. Mr David Gorham, the General Manager of the Rockingham Chamber of Commerce, told the inquiry that the Chamber had been discussing zonal policy charges since 1952. Both Mr Gorham and the Rockingham Shire Clerk, Mr Gary Holland, pointed out that Rockingham is joined socially, economically and in terms of unbroken development to Fremantle and Perth.

Mr Alec Wood, Director of the Armadale and Districts Chamber of Commerce, must be congratulated for his efforts to co-ordinate submissions from the Byford area , and Mrs Orlando, from Orlando Realty and Travel Service in Byford, in her submission mentioned the cost of the STD phone calls and the problem of not being able to check on the costings, even though people often felt they were overcharged. Mr Ross Smith and Mr Robert Maxwell, both members of the Executive Committee of the Rockingham Chamber of Commerce, spoke to the inquiry about the grave difficulties of running a business with the STD system. Mr Des Mays, the Rockingham Shire President, gave details of a recent study which showed that more than 80 per cent of the business contacts made from Rockingham go outside the local call area. He said that the STD charging system was a significant factor in keeping new developments and business enterprises away from Rockingham . All the witnesses spoke about the psychological barrier attached to giving an STD number to anybody when people either make a call or speak to people outside that area. This is particularly important when we think of the effect on potential employees. This was a point that came up repeatedly during the inquiry . The unemployment rates are very high in the areas I have mentioned, particularly amongst young people. Many employees hesitate to ring someone who is automatically assumed to be in the country, even though they might in fact be only a few miles down the road.

The same situation applies to businesses. Mr Phillip Davies, from the Small Business Development Corporation in Western Australia, spoke of Rockingham being a glaring example of an anomaly and described some of the significant benefits that would be associated with Rockingham's inclusion in the untimed call zone. Apart from the restriction on STD calls which many businesses place on employees , there is the added difficulty of Rockingham not being included in the Perth telephone book. The same problems apply, of course, to the Byford area. Telecom is, as I understand it, the only authority to treat Rockingham as being outside the metropolitan area, and it has been a constant frustration to the people there that all other authorities-local, State Government and Federal Government- include Rockingham in the metropolitan area. It is when people pick up their telephones that they know that as far as Telecom is concerned they are considered to be living in the country. Yet, as I have already stated, 80 per cent or more of these people ring into the city or go to the city or surrounding areas for employment. As far as everybody who does that is concerned, they are in the metropolitan area and, I believe, have had justified complaints to make for many, many years now about this problem.

Mr Deputy Speaker, as you will have gathered, the Sub-Committee's visit to Perth was extremely productive, and I pay tribute to my colleagues on both sides of this House, as well as to the witnesses concerned, for their contributions to the hearing. The release of the Sub-Committee's report is being eagerly awaited by many people in Western Australia. I know that this Government and Telecom will be strenuous in the search for ways to implement new arrangements to bring our telephone service into line with the requirements and priorities of the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Hawke Government has now been in office for some 18 months and already we are heading towards an election. Over that period it has had no fewer than two Budgets, as well as a minor mini-Budget in May last year. During that period quite clearly it has been unable to develop and apply at least the most significant elements of its grandiose policy package, particularly in the area of the environment. The paucity of the Government's record stands as a constant reminder that this Government was elected on a dream and remains in so many areas of policy far short of its own expectations. Having failed to reach at least the minimum standards of its own Labor policy, with some regret yesterday and again today I had to call on the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen) to resign from his portfolio. Not only has he failed to live up to the expectations of the Labor Party's environment policy, he has also lost credibility amongst those hundreds of thousands of Australians who were foolish enough to believe in him and in the Party he represents. The only honourable thing for him to do is to go back to other areas of his policy and admit that he has been less than satisfactory in his handling of the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning the Minister gave a speech in Sydney where he again gave an account 'of my stewardship in the 18 months since I became the Federal Minister responsible for environmental matters'. It is quite clear that the Minister knows he is under threat. He realises that his record has been less than satisfactory. I ask one simple question: Has he no shame? At what stage is the Government prepared to face the realities that not only do we see the crisis of the Daintree as a demonstration of its failures of policy, but in so many other areas of the environment, in particular the interface between the Department of Home Affairs and Environment and other departments of state, do we see a total breakdown in the Government's capacity to appreciate that the environment is not isolated. It is not something that can be locked up within one area of a portfolio responsibility; it cuts across the complete ambit of all areas of government activity.

I have on previous occasions emphasised some of the shortcomings of specific policy, but I would like today to make certain comments on two areas in particular. We have seen in the last Budget serious cutbacks in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation funds. On the one hand, we see reductions of funding for forestry research, which means effectively that there is less, if any, money for rainforest research through its centres in north and central Queensland. How does this lie beside a Minister responsible for the environment who stated a few months ago, when he opened the rainforest conference at Cairns, that the preservation of rainforest areas is of major concern to the Government. Apart from talk-talk, the Hawke Government is not prepared to make funds available so that the basic research can be carried out. We have the promise of an environmental contaminants authority, which again was a commitment made in the last policy that has not been met. In terms of national parks and wildlife, we have the classic example there of a total breach of policy. In addition, the national kangaroo monitoring study group was established to plan commercial exploitation and to ensure the conservation of kangaroos on both a national and regional basis. Yet there are no funds in the Budget for that group, while at the same time the Minister has permitted the export of kangaroos, and a number of varieties of euros in particular, for which there are no estimates of population in existence. These are all examples of where the Government has failed to take the minimum requirements to protect the Australian environment.

In a wider area of policy such as soil and water conservation, which is currently the responsibility of the Department of Primary Industry, again in the first Budget it allocated about $1m. In this Budget it has allocated another $3m . How does that lie beside a policy which stated so clearly that the Government was going to establish a national soil and water conservation program and to turn back the problems of the Murray Valley? Where are the promised new powers to be given to the Murray River Commission? So little has taken place and no new legislation has yet appeared in this Parliament in these key areas. In terms of the national conservation strategy the Government was very slow to get off the ground, although the principles had been well laid down by the previous Administration. Labor claims to believe in working with the States, but look at the record in that area. In this last Budget only $120,000-an average of $6,000 per year-has been provided by this Government in two Budgets, compared with an average of $370,000 per year under the Fraser Administration. How can States go out and buy unique areas of the Australian environment to protect them for future generations unless funds are going to be provided from their own sources and in particular from Federal sources as well.

The fact of the matter is that this Government is not serious about preserving the environment. It has broken more promises in this area than possibly in any other area of policy, and that is saying a lot because this Government has broken more promises than possibly any other government in Australia's Federal history. On questions such as the Great Barrier Reef the Minister tells us that he has made a considerable extension in the areas covered. That is true as a basic fact; but in his policy he talked about the need to declare the reef to the low water mark. This did not take place. We have for some time been saying that the high water mark was satisfactory, and again he had to admit that the coalition policy was correct.

In all these areas we see backtracking and filling and obfuscation wherever possible. I would like to explain a subject I brought up publicly only two weeks ago. I said in an address in Melbourne that governments would never have sufficient resources, either financial or in terms of personnel, adequately to protect all areas of the Australian environment under threat, especially areas on the east coast of Australia where population densities are rising all the time and where the area of land is obviously a finite resource. I put forward the proposition that the private sector should be encouraged to establish environmental companies controlled by the environment movement, to buy and manage areas of conservation significance. Investments should receive Federal support in the form of a taxation deduction. This objective was met with derision. A member of this House, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) , a well known member of the extreme socialist Left, considered I was propounding a heretical concept of some nature. Apparently it is an appalling suggestion that individual Australians should be given the opportunity to put their money where their concerns are and be prepared to make a financial contribution to the protection of the heritage of their country if they so wish. So what happened? The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment came in here at the behest of the honourable member for La Trobe and did his best to huff and to puff, like a self-inflating balloon and to pour scorn on the proposal that individual Australians should have the opportunity to assist financially the protection of Australia's national heritage.

What is so extraordinary about such a proposition? Are we to be the only country in the Western world which has to depend on government for everything? Are we to be the only country in the Western world which does not see it as the responsibility of every citizen to take a role in defending the heritage and the environment of our society? It is worth noting that in both the United States and the United Kingdom this proposition has been in place for many years. For example, in the United States the Audubon Society and the Sierra Club control over a quarter of a million acres. They own or lease sanctuaries right across America, mainly for wildlife, especially bird life. Because of that they have been able to protect various species which previously were under threat. They control this area. Whether it is owned by the Government under lease to the societies or the societies purchase the land or receive it as a gift, they are acting as a major supplementary resource to governments and are able to protect so much more.

We find the same situation in the United Kingdom, where the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds owns or leases, again mainly from the state or individuals, and manages a series of reserves ranging from one acre to more than 1,000 acres right across the country. There are 32 of them in England, three in Wales, 14 in Scotland, and four in Northern Ireland. They employ full time wardens and part time wardens. The land is acquired by a private company with funds provided by its members and also from commercial sources. The important thing is that the National Trust in the United Kingdom, as well as the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, owns or leases land as a supplement to what governments can do to protect the environment. When I supported this proposition in this place and in this country, I was met with derision by a Minister for the environment! How awful that any person should suggest that individual Australians should be prepared to be involved or that the environmental movement , which has a view of what standards of management be in place, should be prepared to establish a private company, and say to individual Australians: 'We ask you to buy shares in this organisation so that we can buy areas which are currently under threat'. In that context I suggest that parts of southern Daintree, which are currently for sale, may well be an area which should be looked upon as a first test to demonstrate that the average Australian is concerned with protecting the Australian environment and that we are able and willing as a people to look after our heritage for future generations of our citizens, even when Labor governments are unwilling to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beddall Mr D.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance today is the lack of concern shown to the primary industry sector in the National Party rural policy. In my own electorate of Fadden genuine primary producers, particularly dairy farmers, have been disadvantaged by sweetheart deals between the National Party and the huge conglomerates around the Brisbane area. Prior to last year's State election there were allegations that milk quotas were being flogged off to the highest bidders. Those bidders were leading members of the National Party. The result was an outrageous disadvantage suffered by dairy farmers around Beaudesert. The benefactors were the National Party interests who control the Gold Coast area. Queensland consumers also suffered badly under this agreement. They pay 12c a litre more for milk than consumers in any other State in Australia. There is no doubt that when the National Party gets its hands on something it rigs it to suit its big and powerful friends. If we look at the situation of the Babinda sugar mill from 1974 to 1983, the mill was run in that time by a National Party member of Parliament. Today the mill is in serious financial difficulties. The sugar industry in Queensland is in a state of total collapse, due solely to National Party inaction. The National Party can claim $50m for racing in Queensland but cannot assist the sugar industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party in Queensland is a national disgrace. It is obsessed with real estate developments and little else. The Queensland economy is in a state of contraction and confusion. The industrial base in Queensland is so narrow that the only hope for jobs and employment is through tourism. Tourism has been promoted very well by this Government, particularly by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown). It is no wonder the Queensland Premier wishes to control Question Time in such a way that members cannot ask probing questions of the National Party. The Nationals can get away with this only because of two former Liberals who deserted the Liberal Party. The Queensland coalition crisis has now come to a Federal level. They are standing candidates against one another in the next election and the Premier has said he will not campaign on behalf of the coalition because it will not face up to its responsibilities in addressing problems with the Government. The National Party now says the Liberals are a trendy group and even the so-called candidate for the Northern Territory has little to say on behalf of the coalition.

It is an absolute disgrace that this situation can exist. The people who are missing out are rural Queenslanders. The National Party professes to champion these people, but in its rush to protect powerful interests it has deserted them people. Last Friday I asked a question in this Parliament concerning the Egg Board and all the National Party members could do was sit and make inane farmyard noises. That is their response to the egg producers in my electorate. The National Party certainly has nothing to crow about in this regard. We hear day after day in this House how the deficit is too large and our taxes are too high. Yet the National Party rural policy will cost $312m on top of the $316m that will be spent this financial year.

I ask: Where will the extra money come from? What primary industry measures will be cut back to pay for the big tax cuts? What primary industry measures will be cut back to lower the deficit? Let the National Party do something it has never been able to do before. Let it be honest enough to say what it would cut back. Perhaps the best way is to look at what it did in government. In the wool industry it slashed wool promotion funds and sold off the Australian Wool Testing Authority. It halved the interest rate subsidies for the wheat industry, and I will be reminding growers of that in the Darling Downs in the forthcoming election. It did nothing about restructuring the meat and livestock industry organisations. It presided over a meat substitution scandal which has permanently damaged the meat export industry. It presided over the Asia Dairy Industries scandal, and the former National Party member for Gippsland was found out. It panicked on the drought, it ran down funding for the rural adjustment scheme, and it wiped out the national soil conservation program. The National Party has the hide to come to this House and complain about the amount given to research. A total of $27m has been allocated to the Rural Industry Research Fund . This is an increase of $5m over last year's expenditure. With a National Party Minister, a mere $279,000 was given to this important part of research-a very shameful record indeed.

They do not care about the rural producer. The National Party rural policy is a return to the day of the handout mentality of the past. It is a policy that has sent the New Zealand economy into a decline, and the National Party wishes to emulate that in Australia. National Party policy will not keep up our export industries and will not have them on a competitive level internationally. It fails to realise that we are exporting in world trading conditions and that it is far better to ensure that our primary industries are viable and profitable on a world market. I have a number of small crop farmers in my electorate who live in the suburb of Rochedale. They are small crop farmers and are used to market conditions. They compete on the Brisbane market in open and fair competition. They seek no handouts from the Government. All they ask is to trade on fair and honest marketing arrangement. The National Party handout philosophy does not do this.

Our rural industries need investment, not handouts. Money spent on soil, land, water and forestry is money well spent. Funds spent on research extensions and promotions makes far more sense than money spent to meet the short term needs for political purposes. In Queensland we have seen what happens when the National Party interferes with statutory authorities. The rorts going on in the Peanut Marketing Board in the Premier's own electorate show this. These authorities need to function better in order effectively to service primary producers. Funds to help those authorities become effective exporters are worthwhile investments. It is clear that, with the coalition leaderless and in disarray, it offers nothing for primary producers. I believe that farmers and those dependent on the rural industry should be well rewarded for the--
