QUESTION.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Science and Technology, continues our public debate held earlier on the front lawn.
—You did very well, too.
—I thank the honourable gentleman very much. I refer the Minister to his statement last evening at page 1155 of Hansard where he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the consequence of modest Budget support would be a backlash from those who supported our-
strategies and whose business is science and technology.
. . . as a nation we have to face up to the implications of this, and they are very serious.
Will the Minister tell the House, first, the strength of the backlash and, secondly, the implications of the Budget cutbacks for future jobs and sustained economic recovery?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is undoubtedly a backlash in the scientific community but it is not aimed specifically at this Government. This is a recognition that, over seven lean years under the Fraser Government-honourable members opposite all went along with it--
—An unprecedented demonstration outside the Parliament; never happened before.
—That is the nature of the unprecedented. There is a backlash within the scientific community. There is no doubt that scientists are not exactly pelting us with rose petals--
—You promised the world.

—No, I did not promise the world. I made a prediction, which I quoted last night, in May 1982 that I thought five things would happen: First, we would win the next Federal election; secondly, we would inherit an economic shambles; thirdly, we would bring out a science and technology policy which was generally regarded as the best the nation had ever seen; fourthly, that priority in the Budget would be given to economic and social reform, and, fifthly, there would be a backlash in the scientific community. I recognise that and I am concerned about it. Nevertheless, I went along with the overall Budget strategy because I am conscious that there is a different climate for science and technology from that of two years ago. The States are in the act now when they never were before. The banking system is taking an active role when it never did before. There are significant elements of the private sector that were never in it before.
—Are you working yourself out of a job?
—My future in the job is in the hands of the Prime Minister.
—You are very secure.

—He tells me that I am very secure. We have had to bring about a fundamental change in thinking. I said in the election policy in March 1983 that we would encourage a doubling of expenditure in research and development over the next five years on the basis that virtually the entire increase came from the private sector. That was what we promised in the election. We did not say that there would be vast increases in the amount of government funding. There needs to be that recognition by the private sector. The situation is very serious in some areas. That has to be looked at, but as part of a long term strategy, to encourage overall economic growth. It is the overall strategy that is essential.

—Is the Treasurer aware of claims by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that the Government's legislation to recoup tax lost through bottom of the harbour schemes is immoral? Does the report of the Special Prosecutor, Mr Gyles, QC, indicate that hundreds of millions of dollars of tax revenue will be lost because the former Government's legislation collects only tax evaded in respect of company profits and not the tax in respect of retained earnings distributed to former shareholders? Does this demonstrate that the Government's legislation would collect tax properly payable to the Commonwealth and that the rejection of this legislation by the Opposition means that the beneficiaries of bottom of the harbour schemes will retain the benefit of those blatant abuses of the tax system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Gyles report, tabled in the Senate today, is a damning indictment of the policies of the former Government and of the continuing approach to tax avoidance taken by the Opposition, in particular by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Gyles report not only reveals the magnitude of these taxation losses but also the Opposition's continued protection of the tax avoidance industry in this Parliament. On four occasions now the Government's legislation has been defeated. Despite that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition gets up in this House moralising about the policy which the Opposition now pursues in opposing this matter. Let me quote Mr Gyles on the former Government's record. All honourable members should listen to this intently. He says:

ANSWER.PARA: Tax avoidance and evasion of this kind in such volume is extraordinary in absolute terms but almost incredible in relative terms having regard to the small Australian economy. It has recently been reported that the largest United States revenue fraud case ever brought is being heard-it involved $US48 million. The two committals currently being heard involve revenue loss-
in this country-
of well over $200 million.
He goes on to say:
If there had been an adequate administrative, judicial, and political response in the first place the situation would never have arisen.

That is the report of a special prosecutor appointed by the former Government; not appointed by us. Mr Gyles was appointed by the former Government. That is his damning indictment of the tax avoidance which went on in this country. He sees that as a political responsibility. He says:
If there had been an adequate . . . political response in the first place the situation would never have arisen.

There cannot be anything more pointed than that. Where does the political response fall? The Deputy Leader of the Opposition may not be interested in the answer because he is totally embarrassed by it because he was the Treasurer when these shocking frauds on the revenue occurred and he is now damned by a prosecutor appointed by his own Government. What Mr Gyles says about this loss is this:

I am pleased to note that it has been agreed that assessments will be raised in a series of cases in order to test the application of S.260 in the company stripping field, both as to current year profits and-
wait for it-
undistributed profits.

This statement is of profound significance because this Government is seeking to get the Senate to agree to raise the taxes on those undistributed profits which Mr Gyles now says we must chase with section 260 because the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong, and the Leader of the Opposition opposed the passage of the Government's bottom of the harbour legislation. Yesterday in this Parliament we had the Deputy Leader up on a matter of tax avoidance lecturing and moralising about why members of the Opposition disgracefully--

TALK.START.PARA: —And we had the Minister for Finance up.

—You just listen. You were up here moralising yesterday about the morality of the Opposition in the Senate. The Deputy Leader on a matter of public importance was moralising about why members of the Opposition are opposing the collection of tax on undistributed profits. And yet here is a report of a prosecutor, appointed by his Government, saying that because we cannot get legislation in the Senate for undistributed profits taxes we now have to go to the root of section 260. That makes a total mockery of the opposition to the Government's legislation in respect of bottom of the harbour schemes. In other words, the Opposition has no moral position; it has been blown away by Mr Gyles, the prosecutor appointed by the previous Government. That is the fact of the matter. His report shows that bottom of the harbour legislation introduced by the former Government will not recoup much of the avoided tax from bottom of the harbour schemes. Yet yesterday the Deputy Leader stated:

ANSWER.PARA: Our legislation-the Fraser Government's legislation-recoups all of the illegally evaded tax under bottom of the harbour tax arrangements
That is a lie which Mr Gyles nails.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Treasurer knows he should withdraw that term.
—I withdraw the word 'lie', Mr Speaker. That is an untruth which Mr Gyles nails as an untruth because he understands--
—Will you be here for the personal explanation? I feel one coming on.

—I understand the honourable member. He is embarrassed by his predicament. He proposed himself as a leader. When this other gigolo falls over he will propose himself as the leader of a major party in this Parliament. Yet the honourable member stands here protecting the tax avoidance industry. He is damned by his own prosecutor.
—I raise a point of order. The Treasurer is talking about standing next to tax evaders. He is sitting next to one.
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. Once again I remind the House that the Treasurer has the call and should be allowed to be heard.

—The honourable member for Bennelong will propose himself as the leader of his Party in the not too distant future. There is a view that because he fell into every microphone put under his nose, because he agreed to every interview that was ever asked of him, he is not a bad fellow. The fact is that he supported tax avoidance in this country. He stands here with the most damning record of any Treasurer in the history of this Commonwealth. Here is Mr Gyles saying that bearing in mind the size of the Australian economy which is one- tenth of the size of the economy of the United States of America, the magnitude of the fraud is $200m apiece against $48m for the largest fraud ever committed in the United States. That is the degree of avoidance that went on under the former Treasurer's administration.

ANSWER.PARA: One would not mind if indeed Opposition members passed the Government's legislation on undistributed profits tax, as Mr Gyles suggests they should. We get the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Opposition up moralising and in fact protecting the rip-off merchants that are part of the Liberal Party of Australia. They have always protected the rip-off merchants, frauds and crooks both in government and now in opposition.

I wind up on this point: The Gyles report is the most damning report of the former Treasurer. Mr Gyles is a prosecutor appointed by the former Government and it makes a mockery of the opposition in the Senate to the Government's bottom of the harbour legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct the attention of the House to the presence in the gallery of Minister Tizard from New Zealand who is not an infrequent visitor to Australia and of Mr Ila, a member from the Parliament of Papua New Guinea. Although we usually restrict our mention of visitors in the gallery, we do have in the gallery members of the newly appointed Sports Commission. They include Olympians Betty Cuthbert, Glynis Nunn and Grant Kenny. I felt it appropriate that I direct the attention of the House to that fact and offer them a warm welcome.

—My question is addressed to the Treasurer in his capacity as Minister responsible for the taxation law. I refer the honourable gentleman to his refusal yesterday to refer to the Commissioner of Taxation the new material I raised regarding the tax avoidance activities of the Minister for Finance. In view of that refusal, will the Treasurer now ask the Minister for Finance to give his assurance, first, that the sale of the shares in the Minister's company actually took place on New Year's Day, outlining who was present at the sale; secondly, that the opportunity to backdate the sale by some months that was provided by the registration of the transfer not taking place until April was not taken; finally, that Coomel Pty Ltd and the Minister for Finance did not avoid the consequences of the bottom of the harbour legislation by misleading the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation by incorrectly claiming that a transaction took place at a time that was backdated and at a price that was below the price ruling at the time the transaction was actually decided on?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not find anything exceptional about the fact that shares are registered after a sale; most shares are registered after a sale. Of course, the Leader of the Opposition-he stumbled in his indecent haste yesterday-sent a letter to the Taxation Commissioner. The administration of the tax Act is, by statue, the responsibility of the Taxation Commissioner, not of me. The former Treasurer knows that. He has answered similar questions on half a dozen occasions. The honourable member should not get up here moralising about tax avoidance. We do not want to hear any moralising from him.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for Bennelong, as the former Treasurer, was in absolutely anything in the tax avoidance game. For five years little Johnny Howard was up to his proverbial--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is imputing an improper motive there.
—Mr Speaker, it is not an improper motive. He was the Minister in charge of the tax Act and for five years he was lectured by the Commissioner of Taxation about massive tax avoidance.
—I point out to the Treasurer that it sounded like a personal imputation rather than a reference to his speech.

—I make only this point: For five years the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Bennelong, was written to repeatedly by the Commissioner of Taxation, in what is now the famous telephone book of letters, looking for the political will to which Mr Gyles refers to tackle tax avoidance in this country. He is still running around saying that tax avoidance is dead and all the rest. There was a very interesting statement by his colleague in the Senate today--
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order--
—It is getting too hot for you, John. You can never cop a bagging.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition wishes to raise a point of order.

—I take the point of order that I asked a question about the tax avoidance activities of the Minister for Finance and, thus far, the Treasurer has totally avoided and evaded any reference to the tax avoidance practices of the Minister for Finance.
—There is no point of order.
—It pays to cock an ear to the Senate. This morning I was listening to Senator Durack speaking on the tabling of the Gyles report. He had this to say:

ANSWER.PARA: The statistics that are revealed here show, if anything, how much greater the task was, how much greater the problem was, how much greater the threat to the revenue of this country was, than was believed two years ago, even in the wake of the McCabe-Lafranchi report which, of course, led in the first place to action being taken by the Fraser Government. Subsequently there was the report of the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, immediately in the wake of which the Special Prosecutors Act was passed and Mr Gyles appointed.

So today Senator Durack said that the problem was much bigger. Yet he was the Attorney-General and the honourable member for Bennelong was the Treasurer. They sat on their hands for five years while the Commissioner of Taxation implored them to do something about the hundreds of millions of dollars ripped off by the shonks in the bottom of the harbour business and the other paper schemes. So we will not have any lecturing in this Parliament from the honourable member for Bennelong about tax avoidance or have him asking about anything. There is a statutory responsibility in the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation. He has already cleared the Minister for Finance. I believe that no information provided by the honourable member yesterday was any different from what the Commissioner had previously. If, indeed, it is different, it is for the Commissioner to make a judgment about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Finance give details of trends in funding in the Commonwealth Budget for capital purposes over the past nine years and, in particular, of how the past two years compare with the previous seven years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address an issue which is of great interest to the entire country, as distinct from those issues which occupy the small minds of those opposite. The honourable member for Herbert raised a very interesting question about the composition of the Budget, particularly in relation to its capital and recurrent components. He drew attention to the fact that the Government has made a particular commitment to increasing capital expenditure, notwithstanding the difficult financial situation which we inherited and over which we still preside . In relation to north Queensland, of course, there have been some spectacular new investments and important infrastructure. I refer first to Bob Hawke's Burdekin dam--
—The Lindsay Burdekin dam.

—I refer, then, to the Lindsay-Hawke Burdekin dam on which expenditure this year will be $19m. Expenditure on Commonwealth accommodation for 1984-85 is $7.4m in Townsville; $300,000 on Thursday Island and a commitment of over $6m in Mackay. The airport at Townsville is a matter that will soon be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works.

ANSWER.PARA: This goes to a more important question about the total irresponsibility of our predecessors, particularly the poor and shocking financial mismanagement of the failed former Treasurer. If one looks at the criticism which has been made of this Budget by the failed and discredited former Treasurer, one finds that he has completely ignored the fact that he presided over a total disintegration, a total neglect of the important Commonwealth assets around this country. The former Government inherited a situation in which capital expenditure in the Budget was about 20 per cent of outlays. It declined by more than half to 9 per cent of outlays during that Government's period in office.

The Opposition often talks, of course, about the level of expenditure in this year's Budget compared with that during its period in office. What we find, of course, if we look at the non-capital expenditure during the former Government's period in office, is that it increased by 31 per cent in real terms. We have had to start to redress the dreadful neglect which occurred as the former Government took the easy way out. It took the soft cop in trying to contain government expenditure by simply postponing or abandoning important capital works on behalf of the Commonwealth. Where were these cuts and this neglect most dramatically visited? In the first instance there was a dramatic decline in Commonwealth support for expenditure on public housing. There was also a dramatic decline in support for the accommodation of the Commonwealth, whether in relation to its own offices or for its own employees, particularly in the defence services. We now find that we have a $1 billion headache in trying to redress the neglect of accommodation for Commonwealth employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —So have some taxpayers, thanks to your administration.

—The right honourable member is supposed to have an interest in defence. What has happened? What happened under his brief and hardly startling administration was that the accommodation of defence personnel was reduced to an appalling situation. We now have to redress that problem. If one looks at the record of the former Government's seven Budgets one finds that there were dramatic real declines in capital expenditure which managed during one famous year to decline in real terms by 22 per cent. In five of its seven Budgets there was a dramatic real decline of capital expenditure. This Government has been the first to recognise that there are important differences between capital and recurrent expenditure in our Budget. For the first time we have identified not only the scale of the disaster which we inherited in this area but also the way in which we will redress the problem in this Budget and in future Budgets.

—I address my question to the Prime Minister. It concerns the subject of the suppression of the Press. In view of the fact that the Attorney- General, in the Senate today, twice confessed to having attempted to suppress a story that was to be published in the Age, I ask: Why did a senior adviser to the Prime Minister, Mr Peter Barron, visit the Age last Thursday to have discussions with the Age? During those discussions, did he seek to suppress publication by the Age of material relating to the possession of a safe deposit box in the Union Bank of Switzerland held jointly by a judge of the High Court of Australia and Miss Junie Morosi?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I give the unequivocal negative to that, may I say that the Opposition, in its desperation-week after week it refuses to address any question to the Government and its Ministers about the Budget and the economy-is sinking further and further into the mire of the gutter. Here we have another example. The answer to the honourable member's question is yes, there were discussions between Mr Peter Barron--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —'Woof, woof'-we have a pack of baying woof-woofers. Yes, Mr Barron had discussions with the Editor of the Age and no-unequivocally no-there was no such request as alluded to by this desperate and fast-disappearing member.

—I address my question to the Prime Minister; and this matter ought to occupy the Fourth Estate for some time to come. In the light of recent media speculation, can the Prime Minister advise when the Petrov records will be released?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only will the Fourth Estate be interested; will those opposite, who have this desperate desire for early and immediate release, be interested. Under normal circumstances, the records of the Royal Commission on Espionage-which is colloquially referred to as the Petrov Royal Commission-would be progressively released over the next three years. However, I am very pleased to be able to inform the House that I have approved arrangements allowing for the accelerated release as a single package of the records of the royal commission, related Cabinet material and contemporaneous Prime Minister's departmental files. That will be done on Monday, 24 September 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to see the approbation with which that announcement is greeted by honourable members opposite. Of course extensive consideration has been given to whether any material should be exempted under the provisions of section 33 of the Archives Act.
—Order! The honourable member for Curtin and the honourable member for O'Connor shall cease their conversation.

—They cannot hide their glee and anticipation. After that extensive consideration about the provisions of section 33 of the Archives Act, I am very pleased to say that, in the end, nothing that affects the meaning or the historical substance of the records has been withheld. Obviously, there will be a great deal of interest in these records. Therefore, in anticipation of this interest, the Australian Archives is preparing multiple copies of the key documents and these will be available on 24 September at the Mitchell, Australian Capital Territory, office of the Archives.

—My question is directed to the Special Minister of State. Is it a fact that Mr Costigan has referred 42 separate lines of investigation, not termed reference under the National Crime Authority Act yet, to the National Crime Authority and to its transition team for the drafting of references to the intergovernmental committee? Is it a fact that the 42 separate lines of investigation have been set out in the form of references and each reference has been given a code word? Is it a fact that within the National Crime Authority the 42 separate lines of investigation have now been downgraded to the status of 'material' only? Is it the case that some of the more controversial areas will now never see the light of day as formal references and that the intergovernmental committee will not be shown all 42 separate lines of investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, let me repeat what I said yesterday. It cannot be said that the 42 matters-40 in the first instance and the two that have come subsequently- could have all reached the position of being draft references at any given time. Certainly some references that should be granted will be recommended by the National Crime Authority to the intergovernmental committee. If one looks at the functions of the Authority under the Act, one will see that they are quite complex; they are not just references from the intergovernmental committee. There is the question of other law enforcement agencies that could be involved and State jurisdictions that may be involved in some of these investigations. These matters have not all reached the same level of investigation so far as the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union is concerned. Obviously, the National Crime Authority will deal with them in the manner and at the speed which it thinks it is competent to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: It is not upon my shoulders to upgrade or downgrade material which has been handed to the National Crime Authority. Obviously the Authority will come before the intergovernmental committee saying that it has reached the conclusion that certain matters have now reached the stage where it seeks a reference from the intergovernmental committee. I repeat: It will not just be the material that may be handed over by the Costigan Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —There could be additions.

—There could be additions. For instance, the Australian Federal Police as well as State governments may have matters on which they are seeking a reference to the National Crime Authority from the intergovernmental committee. I do not believe that it was ever intended by the Costigan Commission, from the material which it handed over and the manner in which it was handed over, that it expected the 42 matters would go to the National Crime Authority and there would be an automatic request to the IGC for 42 references at the one time. I think a great deal more investigation is required for some of these matters. Again that is a judgment which will have to be made by the National Crime Authority. Let me reiterate what I said yesterday. I think to some extent we will have to await the final report of the Costigan Commission because a lot of that material will probably add to the 42 matters that have been handed over. The amount of material that has been handed over will now be backed up by a rather lengthy report-the final report-of the Costigan Commission. I would think that the National Crime Authority, quite sensibly, will say: 'We will wait and have a look at this to see its relationship with the material that has been handed over before we go to the IGC'.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said yesterday, in my discussions with the National Crime Authority I have been of the view that perhaps we could call the IGC together for informal discussions with the National Crime Authority prior to the seeking of any references if it thought that appropriate. Those matters are still being discussed between my Department and Mr Justice Stewart. If he thinks that is an appropriate step that is the step that will be taken. Certainly, the matter of when the National Crime Authority is to come before the IGC is the Authority's decision. I have not been given any notice that the Authority wants the IGC called on any date nor have I received any reaction from the National Crime Authority as to its attitude to the material that has been handed over by the Costigan Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Communications to confirm that an Australian Broadcasting Corporation television service is currently planned for 1985-86 to serve the Le Hunte district of the Eyre Peninsula of South Australia? Is it a fact that townships in South Australia such as Moonta, which already receive a television service, will receive an upgraded service under the remote and underserved communities scheme prior to the Le Hunte district receiving the service? Can the Minister explain the thinking behind such a policy?

—Planning has been completed for the establishment of a national television translator on the Eyre Peninsula which will include the Le Hunte district. The new services are currently being scheduled for construction in 1985-86 and their completion is expected in 1986-87. In relation to the second part of the question from the honourable member for Grey, to say that some projects under the remote and underserved communities scheme, such as improving the national television service to the township of Moonta which he mentioned, have already been approved is not correct. I have recently approved criteria for the selection of communities under RUCS to ensure that emphasis is given to the extension of services to areas without any existing service rather than to those which have some sort of service at this stage. I have asked the National Broadcasting Service Planning Committee to report to me before the end of the year on the selection of the first 22 communities.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to the article published on the front page of the Age today, relating to one Stuart John Perry. Despite the enthusiasm of the Attorney-General and the ardour of his staff in promoting the cause of Mr Perry and his re-entry visa, does the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs intend to deport Mr Perry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. This morning I conferred with my departmental officials on that matter. I am informed that for some time the Department has been considering the immigration status of Stuart John Perry and whether he should get permanent residence on the grounds of his marriage to an Australian citizen and adoption of Australian children. The Department has been considering, on the other hand, the fact that he has an extensive criminal record and could be liable to deportation.

ANSWER.PARA: This matter has been around from 1979 to 1983. I shall explain further. A decision by the Department on his status was imminent in August and September 1983, but was postponed because, on 27 September 1983, Commissioner Costigan indicated an interest in questioning Stuart John Perry, and he subpoenaed the Department's files. In retrospect, I believe that in the circumstances it is very fortunate that no decision was taken by the Department or me either to grant permanent residence or to deport him. I am quite pleased about that aspect .

In June this year, the matter was drawn to my attention. I decided to write to Commissioner Costigan saying that I wished to regularise Perry's status one way or the other and asking whether he had any information arising from his investigations that might influence my decision. Commissioner Costigan replied to me giving me a certain amount of material at which we are currently looking. I believe that I should not at this stage make a decision either to deport or to regularise Mr Perry's status. Until we ascertain--

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Storemen and Packers Union been in touch with you on this matter too?
—Listen; this issue has been around since 1979.
—And no Attorney-General has weighed in on his behalf before.
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—Your fellows had a call girl racket going on in Western Australia.
—All the mates again.

—Order! The Minister should resume his seat. While such exchanges are occurring across the chamber, it is useless for the Minister to try to complete his answer. I call the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

—I want honourable members opposite to understand that before I decide whether to deport Perry I am determined to make certain that the Australian Federal Police, State police authorities or the National Crime Authority have no further interest in this man. I am sure that honourable members opposite would agree with that.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, honourable members opposite seem to find some amusement in this matter; I do not. I am determined that this matter will be, as it always has been, handled by this portfolio with absolute probity and with great assiduousness, in the interests of Australia at heart.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Evans, through his staff, simply made a normal representation to me on behalf of a constituent, and that is all there was to that. I ask honourable members opposite to consider the occasions on which they have made representations on immigration matters to past Ministers and to me. I ask whether they checked the past records of each and every individual involved in the multiplicity of representations that honourable members opposite, as individuals, have made to me over the past year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I assume that the Prime Minister is aware that Mr Xavier Connor who has been appointed counsel to the Senate Select Committee on Allegations Concerning a Judge is also chairman of an inquiry into the Special Broadcasting Service. Will his appointment cause delays in the conduct of the Special Broadcasting Service inquiry?
—I take it that the question was to the Prime Minister.

—I have assumed that, Mr Speaker. The honourable member for Diamond Valley asked a very important question. I assure him, and all members of the community who have a particular interest in the affairs of the SBS, that there is no expectation that the dual appointments will cause delays. I remind the honourable member that, in fact, it is not expected that Mr Xavier Connor will be required by the Senate Committee for, I understand, about another five weeks. It is a matter of pride for us all that it was unanimously agreed that Mr Connor was the person to appoint to this recent exercise. We in the Government look forward to the earliest possible completion of the inquiry into the Special Broadcasting Service so that we as a government can ensure that the interests of all involved are properly catered for.

—Does the Minister for Primary Industry agree that the crisis in the grape industry will be further aggravated by the sales tax on wine? Does the Minister agree that a drop in a horticulturalist's income from $290 a week to $ 153 a week in a two-year period is satisfactory? Why did not the Minister instigate an inquiry into the grape industry before imposing a further impost on it? Why has the Minister reduced funds for rural adjustment when the dried fruit , sugar and dairying industries are in need of increased assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Questions about the wine tax come, of course, within the Treasurer's administration. Nevertheless, I shall make some comments on this question because I stand fully behind the Government's decision in this matter-not that there has been much controversy about this, since the Deputy Leader of the Opposition agreed with what the Government is doing. He stated at the National Press Club that he would have to agree that there should be equal tax treatment for all alcoholic beverages.

ANSWER.PARA: With or without the tax, this industry was in a great mess. The inquiry has come about not as a consequence of the wine tax but because of the problems from which the industry is suffering. There is not much sense in referring the industry to the Industries Assistance Commission as a whole. This inquiry will focus on the grape industry and the structure of the grape industry at the wine making and grape growing level. It will focus on such questions as the quality of wine. Instead of every industry immediately going for the reactionary position, it would be a good idea if, once and for all, we started looking outwards a little and worked out ways and means of achieving the international standard for our wine industry that we know it can achieve, going after exports and paying attention to more aspects of quality.

This is a tax on the consumers, not on the grape growing industry. It is very obvious that distortions in terms of equity and tax treatment were getting too great. Consumption of other beverages was going down, whereas the consumption of wine, say, from 1976-1977 had increased by some 46 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about beer?

—The sales tax equivalent on beer is 80 per cent in bottles or 155 per cent in bulk. If the honourable member wants to argue about tax equity he has to face that. It is simply too early to predict the overall effect on the grape growing and wine industries. The cost of casks in the discount stores and supermarkets ranges from $3.99 to about $7 or $8, and I imagine that a 10 per cent sales tax at the bottom end would put about 56c on to the price of a $3.99 cask. The Government thinks this will have no effect whatsoever on sales. As all other beverages are taxed, the sales tax on soft drinks and mineral water being 20 per cent, there are no tax equity arguments as to why there should not be a tax on wine.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member referred also to the effect on grape growers' incomes. Last year an excise levy went on to grape spirit and the prediction was that 100 ,000 tonnes of grapes would be left on the vine. No grapes were left on the vine last year, and comparisons of the consumption of fortified spirits for the months for which we can get comparisons-the levy was on for only a little while- show that consumption held up. In measuring the effects of this tax we simply do not know what will happen. The effects will be masked, and we will not know for quite some time what they are. But it is my prediction and the Government's prediction that there is now such a long term change in taste in this end of the beverage industry that there will be hardly any effects. The inquiry is not about the tax; nor is it consequent upon the tax. It is a constructive and forward-looking approach by the Government.

The final part of the honourable member's question was with respect to the rural adjustment scheme. Unlike the Liberal-National Party Government which took assistance under the rural adjustment scheme right down to $17m at the height of the drought, when we came to office we doubled the RAS component to $35m and spent an additional $11m with respect to the sugar industry, taking the total to some $46m. We responded to the needs of the industry. The rural adjustment scheme is very much geared and directed towards the needs of primary industry. We took assistance under parts A and C of the rural adjustment scheme down from $35m to $25m basically because the States did not spend all the money. As a matter of fact, we had to chase them to spend it, even with respect to the sugar industry. We were also able to divert some $3.1m of the $35m to Western Australia where a special need arose.

If the honourable gentleman had time to read some of the reports with respect to natural disaster relief arrangements from my colleague the Minister for Finance or with respect to the rural adjustment scheme from myself, he would learn that we are moving into a rural adjustment scheme that is open-ended and that no longer will the Government in Canberra or any government be setting the level of rural adjustment assistance. We will be moving to more flexible and more open-ended arrangements from 1 July 1985 wherein the Commonwealth involvement will be in respect of interest payments. We are aware of and do react to the needs of primary industries. We are adopting a lot more flexible approach rather the political whim approach of the National Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, may I have your indulgence to correct what may have been a misimpression gained from my last answer about Mr Xavier Connor? It has been pointed out to me that I may have left the impression in the language I used that he would not be called for five weeks. I apologise if I left that impression. I intended to convey that it is anticipated that he would not be involved for more than five weeks. I am indebted to the House.

—Is the Prime Minister aware of reports that the South African Government has banned public meetings in black townships to avert further unrest ? Is it not a fact that the unrest arises from the perpetuation of apartheid which South Africa has tried to disguise in its new constitutional arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the very important question from the honourable member for Melbourne, I want to say-and I would think that on this I speak for the whole of the House-that we deeply regret the recent violence and tragic loss of life in South Africa's black townships. The situation arises from a combination of circumstances, but the major factor is the growing frustration and anger of the black majority in South Africa in being excluded from participation in the government of their own country. The simple fact is that the more than 20 million blacks who constitute more than 70 per cent of the population of that country are completely excluded from any participation in the election process at the national level. These much-heralded and much-vaunted new constitutional arrangements which extended the franchise to coloureds and Indians represented, as I think is now universally recognised, only a marginal increase in democracy and unfortunately further institutionalised the apartheid system in that country .

ANSWER.PARA: I believe the Australian Parliament and the Australian people should not and will not give any credence to a so-called democracy in which the real power is still held exclusively by the white population, a 'democracy' for which the coloureds and the Indians have shown their contempt by the massive rejection of attendance at the polls and a 'democracy' which can detain non-white community leaders without trial because they oppose the new constitutional arrangements.

The true nature of the South African system was unfortunately underlined by the government measures announced on the 11th of this month which, over a wide area of South Africa, banned until the end of the month all indoor gatherings critical of the Government. Symbolically, a major purpose of the ban is to prevent meetings to commemorate the seventh anniversary of the death in police custody of the black South African fighter for political rights, Steve Biko. This ban on political gatherings follows the detention of more than 40 leading African and Indian activists associated with the multiracial United Democratic Front, the body which led the very successful boycott of the elections to which I have just referred. In this context I use advisedly the words in today's Australian which said:
The panoply of repressive measures taken by the Government strongly recalls the state of emergency after the 1960 Sharpeville massacre . . .

In this House on 4 September, my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs urged the Opposition to reconsider policy declarations that it had made calling for a more accommodating attitude to the apartheid system in South Africa. That is the fact and it is on the record. I repeat the call of the Foreign Minister. I would simply say this: I have had occasion a number of times in the past-and I do so again-publicly to applaud without reservation the totally principled stand taken on this issue by my predecessor, the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser. He has at all times been unequivocal in his opposition to apartheid in South Africa. He has never by word or deed qualified that commitment in any way, and it is a pleasure for me in this place again to commend my predecessor for that continuing totally principled commitment. I express the hope that that position will not be qualified, as it has been, by his successors.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Maranoa raised with me a matter which he suggested was a matter of privilege and which I suggested was a question. He did not get the opportunity to raise the matter in Question Time. Therefore, out of courtesy I think I should respond. The honourable member asked me about the flying of the Aboriginal flag from a flagpole in front of Parliament House. The President of the Senate and I were advised of a recent Government decision, taken to mark National Aborigines Week, to fly the Aboriginal flag on a second flagpole next to or near the national flag on official buildings and establishments. That decision, I understand, was made with no intention that the national flag should be replaced by the Aboriginal flag where only one flagpole was available.

INTERJECT.PARA: The President of the Senate and I considered the matter and decided that the Parliament should similarly mark National Aborigines Week by utilising two poles in front of Parliament House so that the Australian flag and the Aboriginal flag could be flown side by side in front of the House during the week. A similar practice has been followed on other special occasions.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith a motion of censure of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion.
—Mr Speaker, could I ask whether the Leader of the House accepts this motion under standing order 110 relating to censure of the Government.
—No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House censures the Government for
(1) the failure of the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Attorney-General to allow effective investigation into organised crime;
(2) its systematic attempts to weaken the fight against crime in Australia;
(3) its refusal to grant effective powers to the National Crime Authority;
(4) its indecent haste to close down the Costigan Royal Commission in the midst of major investigations;
(5) its deceitfulness over the tabling of correspondence between the Government , the Costigan Royal Commission and the National Crime Authority;
(6) its failure to ensure the continuation of the Costigan Commission's attack on crime by intervening in the dispute over transition arrangements between Costigan and the National Crime Authority;
(7) its failure to institute an effective investigation into the substance of the Age tapes; and
(8) its failure to give the Director of Public Prosecutions effective powers.

For the last two weeks virtually all we have seen in this Parliament is a government twisting, turning and obstructing on the issue of confronting organised crime in this country. The Opposition has exposed the weaknesses of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and duplicity on the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, exposed the Government's irresponsibility on the handover to the National Crime Authority--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Prime Minister going?

—I see that the little crook is running, as he has been running for months as the screws were put on him to wind up Costigan. He is a crook and he knows it. He is a crook and he is running from the Parliament. He is running away from the enforcement of the law.
—Might I suggest to honourable gentlemen on my left that the Leader of the Opposition is addressing the House and that, with the noise they are making, he cannot be heard.

—This little crook is slowly being judged for what he is, a perverter of the law of this country and one who associates with criminals and takes his orders from those who direct those criminals. The Prime Minister was forced, for example, to the early tabling of the Redlich report, which shows the nonsense of the Government's claim to be serious about fighting organised crime. The point is that these events are only one chapter--

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: My concern is that the reference by the Leader of the Opposition may not have been heard by you. He referred to the Prime Minister as a crook. I believe that the Leader of the Opposition should be required to withdraw that statement and to behave himself.

—I point out to the House that, although this is a substantive motion , such a motion does not allow the use of unparliamentary language. If the Leader of the Opposition made that imputation, he should withdraw it.
—The point is that these events are just another chapter--
—The Leader of the Opposition should withdraw.
—I will withdraw the reference to the 'little crook'. Someone may think it relates to his physical--
—Order!

—I withdraw. The point is that these events are just another chapter in the success of a powerful group of people within the Australian Labor Party which will do everything to avoid effective crime fighting and which will do anything to avoid eroding their power base in New South Wales-the same power base of the Prime Minister and the personal fiefdom of the Treasurer (Mr Keating ). We are no longer talking about just a continuation of the historical links between criminals and the New South Wales Labor Party. We now have a systematic attack by the New South Wales right wing to stifle crime fighting and the active complicity of the Prime Minister in this cover-up. When one adds up the events of the last 18 months, one does not have a set of isolated incidents; one has a systematic attempt to weaken crime fighting in Australia and a systematic attempt to obstruct effective investigation by this Prime Minister and his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is this Prime Minister racing to an early election? A salient factor is that he has learned from Mr Wran to get in first before it all comes out. This is the very same Prime Minister who set the standard when he said in September 1982:

But my point is quite explicit in this regard. I say let it all hang out from these inquiries of the Royal Commission and let it fall where it will. They were the words I used in the Parliament and I adhere to that.

The difference between September 1982 and September 1984 is that the Prime Minister's future is now firmly in the hands of a power base which is corrupt, and when the Prime Minister is too tainted the New South Wales Right will spit him out.

Let me briefly detail the events of the last 18 months to show clearly how systematic this attack on crime fighting has been. Firstly, the Jackson affair. It started with Mr Farquhar and Mr Jackson-relative sideshows on the way to the big events-but still it is indicative of the refusal of the Prime Minister and his National President to confront crime. When I first raised in this Parliament the Jackson issue all we got was ridicule and blocking instead of rigorous examination. It is only now that Mr Jackson is being tried. Then one moves to the Age tapes because, if Farquhar, Jackson, Wood and Allen were all about protecting the Prime Minister's mates and power base, the so-called Age tapes provided the first direct test of the Hawke Government's commitment to fight organised crime.

If ever there was a near consensus on crime in Australia, the Age tapes provided it. But what a failure on the part of the Government. Almost a year after the Government became aware of the Age tapes, we are advanced no further towards a full and proper investigation of the Age tapes, tapes which reveal a vast network of crime in Australia. With the exception of Mr Justice Stewart, who is examining the authenticity of the tapes, every other aspect of the investigation into the Age tapes has ceased after a stream of powerless prosecutors. State Attorneys-General have come home saying: 'We lack the power to get to the bottom of the tapes'. We want a royal commission into the Age tapes, with full powers to investigate not only the authenticity but also the substance of the tapes. But of course the Prime Minister will never agree to do this, because he knows that a full investigation would destroy Mr Wran and it would destroy the right wing of the New South Wales Labor Party.

Mr Redlich in his 1983-84 annual report has highlighted the total failure of the Government to confront the information on the tapes. In early 1984 Mr Redlich asked the Attorney-General how the Special Prosecutor might pass to the Victorian gaming squad some information from the Age tapes on race fixing. The Attorney-General did not. When the Opposition raised this issue with the Attorney, he said that there needed to be special legislation to pass the material on. He also said that, because of a mistake in his office, Redlich had not received a reply to his advice.

It seems, considering the history of the Attorney-General's relationship with, for example, Stuart John Perry, that the Attorney makes a lot of mistakes. The key point is this: Why was no legislation passed for some months while this vital information on race fixing, drugs and other aspects of organised crime sat in a file in Canberra? The Attorney-General is quick enough to issue statements attacking people who have information about organised crime but he is a tortoise when it comes to supplying information which is of use to the police. Are these the actions of a government dedicated to fighting crime? Of course they are not.

The Government's record on the National Crime Authority is further proof of a systematic weakening of the fight against crime. It is now a matter of history that, after much vacillation, the Government tried to introduce a crime authority which would have been totally ineffective and that the Opposition had to toughen it up in the Senate. Let me dwell briefly on the transition from the Costigan Commission to the National Crime Authority. Since 30 June the Costigan Commission has had to use all its resources to write the final report. The National Crime Authority is highly unlikely to become operational until December at the earliest. This means that for almost half a year Australia has had no national authority investigating crime. This Government has ensured that major criminals are given a reprieve.

Let us go over the history of Costigan's relations with the Government. Costigan did not want to go on forever. He made that plain in his letters of 1983. He wanted a national crime authority with a power to continue the work that he was doing. I refer to his letter of 10 August. He would then have finished up gladly. The second thing that he wanted was to be able to continue his investigations into financing the big money men on the drug trail. He told the Prime Minister on 2 November that he would like to quit but his investigations were 'at a critical point and it would be contrary to the public interest to stop'. On 24 November he wrote to the Prime Minister and said that he wanted an extension to the end of 1984. His main reasons were 'because it was in the public interest' and that if he were closed down 'it will not be possible to maintain the thrust of my investigations'. He was talking about making sure that his investigations continued unabated in getting to the heart of organised crime in this country.

Did the Prime Minister say: 'Costigan is on the hunt; we will have a crime authority but we will make sure that Costigan nails the big boys'? No. After the December Cabinet meeting in which Keating stuck the knife in and Senator Richardson called the shots from the sidelines, the Prime Minister wrote back: ' You must finish everything, including the transition from your commission to the NCA, by 30 April'. This is a measure of the Prime Minister. This was his acid test. Costigan said 'I can crack these people' and Hawke said 'Finish up'. From there on the correspondence continued, each time with the Government putting pressure on Costigan to finish up and then Costigan asking for a little more warning, a little more time. He warned, for example, on 3 February that if he were forced to finish up his investigations would be destroyed.

Let us remember that, as the screws were tightened on Costigan, from Easter to June he was sick. In that period he was able to sit for only two weeks. The Government would give him a month here and a month there, but never did it relent its pressure. I think the House can imagine just how destabilising that pressure was on the operations of the Costigan Commission. The Prime Minister never said 'You have been sick; have some extra time'-not once. Finally the Government forced Costigan to finish investigations on 30 June, at the end of a period in which he had been able to sit for only a few weeks in the continuation of his investigations.

Now, of course, the Government has given him an extra month-and why not? The Prime Minister has done his job. The investigation finished on 30 June, Costigan is not sitting and his Commission is not investigating. The people he wanted to get back into the witness box cannot be recalled by him. The Prime Minister has done his job. Costigan has been finished. The Treasurer has done his job. Costigan has been finished. Neville Wran, hearing the distant thunder from Costigan, has had his election.

All the facts about the transition have had to be squeezed day by day out of this Government. It was only after persistent questioning that the Prime Minister agreed to table the correspondence on the transition. What did the Prime Minister do after he had been found out in the tabling of that correspondence, and the lack of some of it? Did he apologise? No. Did he say that it was an error that he did not table all the correspondence? No. Instead, he tried to argue his way out of it, claiming that the correspondence did not relate to the transition and to Commissioner Costigan's concerns, when it is so very clear that it did. At every turn this Prime Minister has tried to twist and turn and to obstruct.

But this is not the end of the Government's record of deceit and cover-up. Let us refer to the Redlich report. The Redlich report is a massive condemnation of the worsening situation of the Australian Federal Police. It is also a massive vindication of Mr Costigan. Mr Redlich states that as a consequence of Mr Costigan's work over 600 charges have been laid and there are more to come. This puts the lie to the Attorney-General who criticised Costigan for having a gung- ho approach and who has for the last two weeks been going around Parliament saying that the final Costigan report will be 26 volumes of fiction and one volume of fact.

So much for the words of the Attorney-General. Twenty-four hours before the Redlich report was publicised by the Opposition in this Parliament, the Attorney -General was trying to induce the Government to tip a bucket on Costigan by saying that Redlich's report would show that no charges could be laid on the basis of Costigan's findings. Well, on the basis of how many prosecutions Redlich has already laid, it looks as though the Attorney-General will be wrong again. Mr Redlich has laid 600 charges and there are more to come. Redlich has also pointed to an inadequacy in the powers of the Director of Public Prosecutions. He says that only 30 per cent of the civil remedies that could have been taken against organised crime can at present be taken. This is the legislation of a Prime Minister who so confidently said in 1982:

Any other Royal Commission or any avenue or inquiry which is available to investigate the tax evasion industry and any associated criminal activities should be given those powers so that this industry and any associated criminal activity can be pursued. Let these investigations go where they may and let the results be what they will.

What happened to change the Prime Minister's mind? Who persuaded him to look at the matter differently? We have subsequently had some intimations from Senator Evans that he will seek to remedy the situation. I only hope that he acts with expedition. When we look at the case of Stuart John Perry, we wonder. I come to that matter which my colleagues will dwell on in some detail later in this debate.

The essence of the Perry matter is this: Perry went to Attorney-General Evans in 1983 seeking support for his application for a visa. He told the Attorney- General and his staff that he had a long criminal record. One would think that the Attorney-General might have been somewhat reluctant to support this application. If he had done any investigation of Perry he would have found that Perry had misrepresented to him the number of charges he had had since 1979. If he had probed he would have found that the Costigan Commission was extremely interested in Perry, as we discovered here today. Indeed, shortly after the Attorney-General's support for Perry, Perry spent a couple of interesting days being cross-examined by Costigan.

I refer the House to the publicly available transcripts of evidence of the Costigan Commission of 30 September and 11 October. It demonstrates the immense stupidity of the Attorney-General that it does not seem to have occurred to him that if a man comes before him seeking the Attorney's support over his immigration status, he ought to consider whether or not he might be in the situation eventually of prosecuting or deporting the same man. I can only add to this farce a very serious note. Senator Evans has confessed that, like the Prime Minister, he twice approached the Editor of the Age, seeking to suppress this story. Did he speak to Chadwick or to Perry? He did. Is that why Perry went to the Age and menaced reporters, threatening them, the day after Senator Evans spoke to editor Burns? This is negligence by a Minister which is inexcusable, inexplicable and dangerous.

But the other significant element in this story is the presence of Mr Chadwick of the Storemen and Packers Union. Mr Chadwick is the Storemen and Packers Union standover man. He is the one who puts the heavy on when the Prime Minister's mates in the Storemen and Packers Union-Crean, Landeryou and the like-want to keep any protest in their ranks quiet. The Storemen and Packers Union is one of the Prime Minister's key power bases in the union movement, and Chadwick is one of its key men. He keeps company with this Mr Stuart John Perry-let us put it bluntly; a noted hit man-and the poor fool of an Attorney-General snaps into line when a heavy from the Storemen and Packers Union calls the tune.

What is going on? Where do all the links lead to? Keating, Chadwick, Evans-they all have one thing in common: They are all the Prime Minister's men. All these links will continue to weave a web around this Prime Minister as he struggles to obstruct inquiries into the Age tapes, as he seeks to make sure that never again is there a body so fierce and determined as Costigan, as the Treasurer protects the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) for fiddling his bottom of the harbour schemes, as the Attorney-General seeks to delay action on the Redlich and Gyles reports, as the Attorney-General runs away from his foolish and dangerous behaviour in regard to Perry, as Keating, Richardson and Wran-the corrupt princes of the New South Wales Labor Party-seek to worm out of the revelation of the truths about themselves, and as the Treasurer seeks to cover up the truth about his interference over the Gyles reports. In weeks to come we shall be hearing a lot more about this Government's moral corruption, and about the role that this Treasurer has played as well as the role of the Prime Minister. This Government is deserving of censure today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.
—I say unashamedly that there is more to come, and come it will.
